entry.et: Middle English, from Old English hwisperian; akin to Old High German hwispalōn to whisper, Old Norse hvīsla whistle

def.dt: :to speak softly with little or no vibration of the vocal cords especially to avoid being overheard
:to make a sibilant sound that resembles whispering
:to utter or communicate in or as if in a whisper
:something communicated by or as if by whispering
:speech without vibration of the vocal cords
:a sibilant sound that resembles whispered speech
:a loud whisper by an actor that is audible to the spectators but is supposed for dramatic effect not to be heard by one or more of the actors
